title: How to Stop Other Devices From Connecting to Bluetooth

steps.title: Open your iPhone or iPad’s Settings .
steps.content: Open your iPhone or iPad’s Settings . You’ll usually find this app on the home screen.

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . It’s near the top of the menu.

steps.title: Tap the ″i″ in a circle on the device you want to unpair.
steps.content: Tap the ″i″ in a circle on the device you want to unpair. It’s on the right side of the device’s name.

steps.title: Tap Forget This Device.
steps.content: Tap Forget This Device . It’s at the top of the menu. Now that you’ve unpaired this Bluetooth device, it will no longer automatically connect to your iPhone or iPad.

steps.title: Open your Android’s Settings .
steps.content: Open your Android’s Settings . It’s the gear icon in the app drawer. This method will only work on a Samsung-built Android.

steps.title: Tap Connections.
steps.content: Tap Connections . It’s at the top of the screen. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . It’s the second option.

steps.title: Tap the gear icon next to the device you want to unpair.
steps.content: Tap the gear icon next to the device you want to unpair.

steps.title: Tap Unpair.
steps.content: Tap Unpair . Now that you’ve unpaired this Bluetooth device, it will no longer automatically connect to Samsung phone or tablet.

steps.title: Open your Android’s Settings .
steps.content: Open your Android’s Settings . It’s the gear icon in the app drawer. The names and locations of menu options may vary by manufacturer.

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . It’s near the top of the menu. You may have to tap Connected devices to find the Bluetooth option. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the gear icon next to the device you want to unpair.
steps.content: Tap the gear icon next to the device you want to unpair.

steps.title: Tap FORGET or Unpair.
steps.content: Tap FORGET or Unpair . The name may vary by manufacturer. Now that you’ve unpaired this Bluetooth device, it will no longer automatically connect to your Android.

steps.title: Click the menu.
steps.content: Click the menu. It’s at the top-left corner of the screen. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click System Preferences.
steps.content: Click System Preferences .

steps.title: Click Bluetooth.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth . A list of paired devices will appear.

steps.title: Hover the mouse cursor over the device you want to unpair.
steps.content: Hover the mouse cursor over the device you want to unpair. An ″x″ will appear next to the device’s name.

steps.title: Click the x.
steps.content: Click the x . This unpairs the device. Your computer will no longer connect to this device unless you pair it again.

steps.title: Click the menu.
steps.content: Click the menu. It’s usually at the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Click Settings .
steps.content: Click Settings . It’s on the left side of the menu.

steps.title: Click Devices.
steps.content: Click Devices . It’s the second icon in the top row.

steps.title: Click Bluetooth & other devices.
steps.content: Click Bluetooth & other devices . It’s in the left column.

steps.title: Click the device you want to unpair.
steps.content: Click the device you want to unpair. It’s in the right panel. A ″Remove Device″ button will appear beneath its name.

steps.title: Click Remove device.
steps.content: Click Remove device . A confirmation message will appear.

steps.title: Click Yes.
steps.content: Click Yes . Your computer will no longer connect to this device unless you pair it again.
